div1.p: SECTION I

ORIGINAL CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE SCIENCE OF MEDICINE
BY MEDICAL OFFICERS OF THE ARMY
No. 2

To the vast majority of the human race living today, including
the inhabitants of the Western Hemisphere, the term “yellow fever”
means little more than a name. That mention of this disease no longer
brings to the mind's eye a picture of chaos and terror has resulted
from the researches of a commission of medical officers of our own
Army, headed by Major Walter Reed.

Advances in all lines of human endeavor have been so marvelous
during the past 50 years that we are prone to accept them as a matter
of course and to forget that the comforts and blessings that we now en-
joy are the result of painstaking effort and sacrifice on the part of
individuals or groups of individuals who preceded us. That credit may
be given where credit is due and that we may duly appreciate the bene-
fits we now enjoy, it is well for us, from time to time, to take stock
of the contributions to our well-being made by our predecessors.

It is especially fitting that we recognize and duly appreciate
the debt of gratitude we owe Walter Reed and his co-workers, Carroll,
Lazear, and Agramonte. During the 19th and preceding century, a mere
whisper of the occurrence of yellow fever in a community was synonymous
with a state of panic, chaos, and fright beyond compare.

That we may have some conception of what yellow fever meant to
the inhabitants of the Western Hemisphere for the two hundred years prior
to 1900, let us, for a moment, turn back the pages of history. The earli-
est authentic records indicate that in the 16th and 17th centuries epi-
demics of yellow fever were of common occurrence in Central America and
the islands of the Carribean Sea. In the island of St. Lucia, for example,
in 1664, 1400 of a garrison of 1500 soldiers died of yellow fever, and
again in 1665, 200 of a total military force of 500 succumbed to the dis-
ease. The first epidemics to occur in our own country were those reported
in New York, Boston, and Philadelphia between the years 1668 and 1695.
Between 1800 and 1900 the United States was invaded by yellow fever ap-
proximately 100 times.

During the 19th century, the most devastating of the epidemics oc-
curred in our Southern states, and it may conservatively be estimated
that during this 100-year period approximately 500,000 people had yellow
fever and 100,000 (20 per cent) died. New Orleans bore the brunt, with
about 41,000 deaths; four epidemics in Nemphis claimed approximately 8,000
victims; Charleston, S. C., lost 4500 of its citizens as a result of two
visitations, and 2000 people died in Norfolk, Va., during the course of an
epidemic in 1865. (1)

The more recital of figures gives but little insight into what an
epidemic of yellow fever actually meant to our ancestors, and of this we
must have some conception if we are to evaluate properly the benefits con-
ferred on mankind by the researches of Walter Reed and his associates.
(1) Walter Reed and Yellow Fever, H. A. Kelly)

The testimony of eyewitnesses will best serve to acquaint one
with what actually occurred during an epidemic, and the following ex-
amples are drawn from descriptions of epidemics in Philadelphia, Pa.,
and Memphis, Tenn.

Mr. Mathew Carey, of Philadelphia, a member of the “Committee for
Relieving the Sick and Distressed” during the Philadelphia epidemic of
1793, published a very vivid account of that epidemic, from which the fol-
lowing paragraphs are quoted:

"The consternation of the people of Philadelphia at this per-
iod was carried beyond all bounds. Dismay and affright were visi-
ble in the countenance of almost every person. Of those who re-
mained many shut themselves in their houses and were afraid to
walk the streets * * * * *

"The corpses of the most respectable citizens, even those who
did not die of the epidemic, were carried to the grave on the
shafts of a chair (chaise), the horse driven by a negro, unattended
by a friend or relative, and without any sort of ceremony. People
hastily shifted their course at the sight of a hearse coming towards
them. Many never walked on the footpath, but went into the middle
of the streets, to avoid being infected in passing by houses wherein
people had died. Acquaintances and friends avoided each other in
the streets and only signified their regard by a cold nod. The old
custom of shaking hands fell into such disuse that many shrunk back
with affright at even the offer of the hand. A person with a crape,
or any appearance of mourning, was shunned like a viper. And many
valued themselves highly on the skill and address with which they
got to the windward of every person they met. Indeed, it is not
probable that London, at the last stage of the plague, exhibited
stronger marks of terror than were to be seen in Philadelphia from
the 24th or 25th of August till pretty late in September.

“While affairs were in this deplorable state, and the people
at the lowest ebb of despair, we cannot be astonished at the fright-
ful scenes that were enacted, which seemed to indicate a total dis-
solution of the bonds of society in the nearest and dearest connec-
tions. Who, without horror, can reflect on a husband deserting his
wife, united to him, perhaps, for twenty years, in the last agony--
a wife unfeelingly abandoning her husband on his death-bed--parents
forsaking their only children without remorse--children ungratefully
flying from their parents and resigning them to chance, without an
inquiry after their health or safety * * * ”

At the time of this epidemic (1793) the population of Philadelphia
was 40,000, and 10 per cent (4,000) of the inhabitants died of yellow
fever in one and one-half months (August 1 to September 15).

In 1878, Hemphis and its vicinity was visited by an appelling epi-
demic of yellow fever, which Mr. J. M. Keating, of that city, has de-
scribed in a most graphic manner. The following paragraphs are taken
from his description:

"Men, women, and children poured out of the city by every pos-
sible avenue of escape . . . . Out by the country roads to the
little hamlets and plantations, where many of them were welcome
guests in happier days; out by every possible conveyance--by
hacks, by carriages, buggies, waggons, furniture vans, and street-
drays; away by bateaux, by anything that could float on the river;
and by railroads, the trains on which, especially on the Louisville
road, were so packed as to make the trip to that city, or to
Cincinnati, a positive torture to many delicate women every mile
of the way. The aisles of the cars were filled and the platforms
packed. In vain the railroad officials plead, in vain they in-
creased the accommodations. The stream of passengers seemed to
be endless and they were as mad as they were many. The ordinary
courtesies of life were ignored, politeness gave way to selfish-
ness, and the desire for personal safety broke through all social
amenities. . . . To the cities of the far North and the far West
they fled, too many of them to die on the way like dogs, neglected
and shunned, as if cursed of God; or, to reach the wished-for goal,
only to die, a plague to all about, carrying dismay to those who
even then were busying themselves for the relief of the stricken
cities of the South. In less than ten days, by the 24th of August,
twenty-five thousand people had left the city and in two weeks after
five thousand others were in camp, leaving a little less than twenty
thousand to face consequences they could not escape. . . .

"By the last week in August the panic was over in the city. All
had fled who could, and all were in camp who would go. There were
then, it was estimated, about three thousand cases of fever. . . . an
appelling gloom hang over the doomed city. At night it was silent
as the grave, by day it seemed desolate as the desert. There were
hours, especially at night, when the solemn oppression of universal
death bore upon the human mind, as if the day of judgment was about
to dawn. Not a sound was to be heard; the silence was painfully pro-
found. Death prevailed everywhere. Trade and traffic were suspended.
The energies of all who remained were engaged in the struggle with
death. The poor were reduced to beggary, and even the rich gladly
4.
accepted alms. . . Even the animals felt the oppression and fled
from the city. Rats, cats, or dogs were not to be seen. Death
was everywhere triumphant. White women were seldom to be met with,
children never. The voice of prayer was lifted up only at the
bed of pain or death, or in some home circle where anguish was su-
preme and death threatened, as in a few cases he accomplished, total
annihilation. Tears for one loved one were choked by the feeling
of uncertainty provoked by the sad condition of another. In one
case a family of four was found dead in one room, the bodies par-
tially decomposed. There were no public evidences of sorrow. The
wife was borne to the tomb while the husband was unconscious of his
loss, and whole families were swept away in such quick succession
that not one had knowledge of the other's departure. Death dealt
kindly by these. . . . Neither cleanliness nor right living were
a shield to stay the hand of the destroyer. He invaded the homes
of the most chaste and the den of the vilest. He took innocence
and infamy at the same moment and spread terror everywhere. Where
sorrow was so general there could be no parade of it. There were
no funerals and but little demand for funeral services. The luxuries
of woe were dispensed with. In most cases the driver of the hearse
and an assistant composed the funeral party. Not infrequently many
bodies were left in the cemetery unburied for a night, so hard
pressed were the managers for labour, and so numerous were the de-
mands upon what they had. . . . The churches were closed. The con-
gregations dispersed. The members were far apart. Some were safe,
many were dead. Only a few survived, and these were manifesting
their faith by works. The police were cut down from forty-one to
seven. Their ranks were recruited and again were thinned. They
were a second and a third time filled up, and yet death was relent-
less. He was jealous of all sway but his own.

“Petty thieving prevailed as an epidemic. This was princi-
pally confined to food and clothing, and wood or coal, or both.
A few who came to nurse died, leaving full trunks of silverware,
bijouterie, bric-a-brac, and clothes, to prove how industriously
they could ply two trades and make one cover up and supply the de-
ficiencies of the other.* * *”

It is not to be inferred from the descriptions just quoted that
selfishness and thoughtlessness of others was universal. This was far
from being the case, as is so well brought out by both Mr. Carey and
Mr. Keating. Both writers cite instances of heroism, devotion to duty,
service to humanity, charity, and generosity that are incomparable.

The actions and reactions of the human mind to the unknown and
mysterious are shown in clear relief in the descriptions of these two
epidemics, and when it is remembered that an identical state of mind
existed during all epidemics occurring in our country prior to 1900, one
can more thoroughly appreciate what an epidemic of yellow fever meant
to human beings exposed to it, prior to the discovery of the proper
methods for its control.

Throughout the 19th century, even to its end, the appearance of
yellow fever in a community in our country was accompanied by chaos and
panic, as is evidenced in the following statement made by Reed and Carroll.(1)

“The interval between 1793 and 1888 is almost 100 years, but
upon the appearance of yellow fever we observe no difference of
behavior on the part of the inhabitants of Jackson, Miss., in 1888,
from that shown by the citizens of Philadelphia in 1793, except
that the terror of the former was greater and their flight from
their homes more precipitate than in the case of the latter.”

The investigations of Reed and his co-workers converted a death-
dealing disease, the method of transmission of which was mysterious and
unknown, into one that could be dealt with in the open with the certainty
that it could be stumped out.

Shortly after the method of transmission of yellow fever was an-
nounced to the world, opportunity was afforded, through an epidemic in
New Orleans, to give the knowledge thus gained practical application.
The remarkable alteration in the state of mind of the public is graphical-
ly portrayed by Dr. Kelly and Sir Rupert Boyce. (2)

(1) Prevention of Yellow Fever, Reed and Carroll, Sen. Doc. 822,
61st Cong., 3d Session, 1901, Chap. 6.
(2) 1906, Walter Reed and Yellow Fever, by H. A. Kelly, pp. 193-195.

"A strong proof of the assurance of safety afforded by the
present methods of fighting yellow fever and of the confidence
arising from them is shown by the cheerful spirit with which
the citizens of New Orleans encountered the epidemic of 1905,
and the light-heartedness which pervaded the town, in marked
contrast to the gloom that, in former times, always hung like
a pall over such scenes. Mr. Rupert Boyce, Dean of the Liver-
pool School of Tropical Diseases, who was sent to New Orleans
by that association as envoy charged to investigate yellow fever,
has described this state of things most graphically in the
Southern Magazine for October, 1905.

'In one respect New Orleans has set an example to all the
world in the fight against yellow fever. Coming, as I did, a
stranger, but a stranger who has seen many campaigns against
similar diseases, the first impression that struck me was the
complete organization of the citizens, and the rational and
reasonable way in which the fight has been conducted by them.
When I alighted from the car the first thing that greeted my
eyes was a placard--of which tens of thousands have been dis-
tributed--bearing the words:

Wear a Smile on Your Face
and a
Flower in Your Buttonhole.

'Everywhere I went I saw these. The force with which such
evidences of the light-hearted spirit in which the citizens
of New Orleans sallied forth to win this fight strikes one who
has been a witness to the profound gloom, distress, and was
that cloud every other epidemic city cannot be estimated.

'That is the spirit which has led to victory. That is the
light heart and gay song which nerves the warrior to invinci-
bility. To go at the enemy laughing, and to fight with a
jest, means always to overcome with a glorious victory.

'When I came, in the first part of September, I found the
whole country organized. The municipality was organised by
wards; the medical profession was organized by flying squadrons;
the State was organized by parishes. With a tangible enemy in
view, the army of defence could begin to fight rationally and
scientifically. Every individual citizen of every city and town,
but especially of New Orleans, had taken to himself new heart
of grace, because he knew what he had to fight.

'To me, coming as I did from many campaigns against tropical
diseases in many an odd corner of the world, this ogganization
appealed more strongly than I can say. An example to the world
has been set, an example to every city in the civilised world
which shall henceforth be attacked by similar diseases.

‘And the work of the Marine Hospital Service struck the heart
of the beholder with joy. Cleanly, swiftly, scientifically, the
7.
olive-green uniforms darted hither and thither, into dens of
filth and obscurity, opening up every corner to the bright
light of science, working heroically, and withal so swiftly
that it was like watching a huge machine, well oiled and ef-
ficacious, performing a marvellous task with perfect show of
ease.’"

So far we have considered yellow fever with respect to its in-
fluence on the minds of members of the human race exposed to it. It
will be well for us also to review briefly the effects of epidemic on
the public welfare. It is recokoned that the human lives lost in the
United States from yellow fever during the 19th century was approximate-
ly 100,000 and this death rate, fearful though it be, represents only
in part the hardships and distress occasioned by epidemics. The financial
loss was both direct and indirect and fell, without discrimination, on
the individual, the community, and on commercial interests. Business
was disrupted, transportation interrupted and quarantine regulations were
exacting, with all the pecuniary losses that such chaotic conditions en-
tail. The epidemic of 1878 was perhaps one of the most widespread in-
vasions of the United States by yellow fever, beginning with New Orleans
as the primary focus, extending as far north as Missouri, involving 132
towns and cities in eight states, and claiming approximately 75,000 vic-
tims, of whom about 16,000 died. It is conservatively estimated that
this one epidemic cost the United States $100,000,000, and the pecuniary
loss to New Orleans alone exceeded $10,000,000. In 1897, an epidemic in
Texas and Louisiana resulted in a loss exceeding a million dollars to the
Southern Pacific Railway Company, on its lines operating in those states.
The enforcement of the complicated quarantine regulations in vogue during
8.
the 19th century--wholesale disinfection of houses, premises, baggage,
freight, mail steamships, etc.; formation of detention camps and deten-
tion of passengers traveling by railway, steamship, and otherwise; regu-
lation of traffic, and other restrictive measures of like nature, inter-
fered with business relations of one kind or another and entailed finan-
cial losses, the magnitude of which is impossible of estimation. It was
possible to eliminate most of the measures of this nature when the mecha-
nism of transmission of the disease became known.

The occurrence of epidemics of yellow fever are contingent on the
concurrent presence of three factors, namely, cases of yellow fever, ade-
quate numbers of mosquitoes (Aedes egypti), and susceptible individuals.
Appreciation of this fact will permit one to visualize what might have
happened at any time in this age of rapid transportation did we not know
how to prevent the introduction and spread of yellow fever. The mosquitoes
are present in abundance, the entire population is susceptible, and the
introduction of the third factor, a case of yellow fever, would initiate
a conflagration the horror and extent of which would be beyond human con-
ception. As a matter of fact, a very striking object lesson of what could
occur can be cited. There is another disease, dengue fever, which from
time to time has invaded some of our Gulf states, notably Texas and
Louisiana. During recent years it has been demonstrated that this disease
is transmitted by the yellow fever mosquito (Aedes Egypti)) and an Army
Research Board, working in Manila, P. I., during the past year has shown
that dengue is transmitted in exactly the same manner as is yellow fever.
In 1922, dengue appeared in Texas, with incredible rapidity swept across
the Southern states from Texas to Georgia, and attacked not less than two
9.
millions of people. The rapidity of its spread was undoubtedly due
to the numerous improvements in transportation facilities during the
past 10 years. Fortunately, dengue causes temporary disability only and
does not result in death. To visualize “what might have been”, it is
only necessary to substitute the dreadful name yellow fever for dengue.
More than 2,000,000 individuals would have been attacked and approximate-
ly 400,000 would have died, chaos would have reigned, and the pecuniary
loss would have been of such magnitude as to stagger the imagination.
The work of the Army board in Cuba made such a calamity impossible. To
say that the work of this board has resulted in a saving to our Government
and its people of many times the amount of money reqired to operate the
Medical Department of the Army from its inception to the present day, is
expressing the matter conservatively.

Having gained some conception of what epidemics of yellow fever ac-
tually meant to our people during the 19th century, it remains for us to
take into consideration the facts established by Reed and his co-workers
that have resulted in the banishment of this disease from the North American
continent, and doubtless, within a short period of time, will eliminate
it from its few remaining haunts throughout the world.

Prior to the epidemic occurring in Philadelphia in 1793, apparently
no theories with respect to its origin and mode of transmission had been
evolved, and its occurrence was accepted, without question, as being a
visitation of God. Its appearance in Philadelphia caused much specula-
tion on the part of the medical profession of that day, and two hypotheses
arose. One group hold that the disease was imported and therefore trans-
10.
missible from person to person, while the other adhered to the view
that it originated locally and resulted, under appropriate conditions,
from a combination of filth, heat, and moisture (spontaneous genera-
tion). Toward the end of the 19th century it was held, generally, that
yellow fever was a transmissible disease caused by a specific living
germ. The method of transmission from person to person was an unsolved
mystery, but it was generally believed that the germ could be transported
from place to place by persons, in baggage, etc., hence the elaborate
quarantine regulations. In the last decade of the century, two or three
investigators reported that they had found the specific germ, but their
claims wore disproved. About the middle of the 19th century (1848),
Doctor Mott, of Mobile, suggested that yellow fever and malaria night
be transmitted by insects. Nothing, however, of a definite nature with re-
spect to the role possibly played by mosquitoes in the dissemination of
yellow fever appears in medical literature until 1881, when Dr. Carlos Finlay,
of Havana, Cuba, announced and defended the theory that mosquitoes were
the transmitting agents. He continued to hold this view and suggested
further that a particular species of mosquito, now known as the Aedes egypti,
was responsible. Finlay was never able to demonstrate the truth of his
theory, but this species of mosquito was the one finally incriminated by
the Reed commission, and Walter Reed's decision to use it in the initial
experiment made by the commission was based on information given him by
Doctor Finlay.

Two other facts that had been established late in the 19th century
influenced Reed in his decision to attempt transmission by mosquitoes.
11.
The first of these was the fact that when groups of people or bodies of
troops were moved out of infected areas ordinarily no further cases of
yellow fever would occur in the groups so transferred. This suggested
that the germs of the disease were not carried along by the individuals
themselves. The second observation, made by Doctor Carter of the U. S.
Public Health Service, was that if an individual came down with yellow
fever in a house in a previously uninfected locality, no secondary cases
of the disease arose in the same house until a period of two to three
weeks had elapsed. This suggested that it was necessary for the yellow
fever virus to develop or mature for about two weeks before it could pro-
duce the disease in other individuals, and indicated definitely the prob-
ability that an insect was its intermediary host.

When our military forces occupied Cuba during the Spanish-American
War, yellow fever immediately appeared, and between July, 1898, and
December, 1900, 1576 cases occurred and 231 deaths resulted.

The War Department, on the recommendation of Surgeon General
Sternberg, who had done much pioneer research work on yellow fever, de-
cided to dispatch a commission of Army medical officers to Cuba to investi-
gate yellow fever and other prevailing tropical diseases. The commission
was headed by Major Walter Reed, the other members being Acting Assistant
Surgeons James Carroll, Jezse W. Lazear, and A. Agramonte. The commission
arrived in Cuba in June, 1900. They very quickly convinced themselves
that the living organism causing yellow fever had not been discovered,
as had been alleged by some investigators. They then turned their atten-
tion to the production of the disease experimentally in human volunteers
through the bites of mosquitoes. Within a few months their efforts were
12.
crowned with success. It is not within the scope of this note to enter
into any of the details of their investigations. They have been made of
record by Dr. Howard Kelly, of Baltimore, in his volume “Walter Reed and
Yellow Fever” and in a Senate document (no. 522, 61st Congress, 3d Session).
Expressed briefly, it was found that the mosquito responsible for the dis-
semination of yellow fever was the female of the species Aedes egypti, then
known as Stegomyia fasciata; that to become infected the mosquito must
take blood from the individual with yellow fever during the first three
days of his illness; that the mosquito is incapable of transmitting yellow
fever for a period of approximately 12 days subsequent to biting a patient
in the infectious stage of the disease; that once a mosquito becomes cap-
able of transmitting yellow fever by its bites it retains that capacity
for long periods of time (55 days or more); that the incubation period
of the disease does not exceed six days; and that the germ, whatever it
may be, is extremely minute in size and passes through porcelain filters
that hold back the bacteria that ordinarily cause disease.

Reed's previous training, logical habits of thought and attention
to detail fitted him peculiarly well for the position of directing head
of the commission, and the series of experiments were so brilliantly con-
ceived, so comprehensive, so simple, and so well executed that the facts
reported by the commission were immediately accepted by scientific author-
ities throughout the world. The practical lesson to be drawn from the
facts demonstrated were well expressed by the commission in the following
language; “The spread of yellow fever can be most effectually controlled
by measures directed to the destruction of mosquitoes and the protection
of the sick against the bites of these insects.”

It was practicable, immediately, to subject these conclusions to
practical test. In the city of Havana, Cuba, yellow fever had prevailed
every year for at least the preceding 140 years and was present at the
time the commission's report was made. General Leonard Wood was military
governor of Cuba at that time, Col. Jefferson Kean was sanitary adviser
to the Military Governor, and Major (later Major-General) Gorgas was health
officer of Havana. The splendid results obtained in the campaign against
yellow fever in Havana are known to the world. Within a period of 90 days,
Havana was released from the grip of this dread disease. Its last appear-
ance in the United States was in 1906, when New Orleans was invaded. This
epidemic also was brought to an end by an active, well organized anti-
mosquito campaign.

Since 1905, yellow fever has been rapidly vanishing from the Western
Hemisphere, and is now confined to a few of its ancient strongholds in
Central America, occasionally appearing in nearby localities. The Interna-
tional Health Board, one of the Rockefeller foundations, is devoting much
attention to the eradication of the disease in its for remaining foci of
endemicity throughout the world, and it may safely be predicted that in
the near future this dread disease will become a more memory to mankind.

The very high regard in which Major Reed was held may be gauged
by the following sentiments of respect expressed by friends, acquaintances,
and scientists at the time of his death. Brigadier-General McCaw pays him
this tribute of praise:

"It is given to but few scientific men to lay bare a secret
of nature materially affecting the prosperity of nations, and
the lives, fortunes, and happiness of thousands. Fewer still
succeed in so quickly convincing brother scientists and men in
authority of the truth of their discoveries that their own eyes
behold the glorious result of their labor.

“*******To the end of his life it was noticeable that even
when he had long given up the practice of medicine for the work
of the laboratory he was nevertheless unexcelled at the bedside
for rapid, unerring diagnosis and sound judgment in treatment.
So also were the series of experiments which robbed yellow fever
of its terrors especially remarkable for simplicity, accuracy,
and completeness, or they never would have so quickly convinced
the world of their truth. Too much reverence for accepted teach-
ings, and too little experience in grappling with difficulties
unassisted, and they might never have been conceived or carried
out.”

Major-General Leonard Wood, Military Governor of Cuba at the time the ex-
periments were carried out, expresses his esteem in the following words:

"I know of no other man on this side of the world who has done
so much for humanity as Dr. Reed. His discovery results in the
saving of more lives annually than were lost in the Cuban war, and
saves the commercial interests of the world a greater financial
loss each year than the cost of the Cuban war. He came to Cuba
at a time when one-third of the officers of my staff died of yel-
low fever, and we were discouraged at the failure of our efforts
to control the disease.

“In the months when the disease was ordinarily worst the dis-
ease was checked and driven from Habana. That was the first time
in nearly 200 years that the city had been rid of it. The value of
his discovery can not be appreciated by persons who are not familiar
with the conditions of tropical countries. Hereafter it will never
be possible for yellow fever to gain such headway that quarantine
will exist from the mouth of the Potomac to the mouth of the Rio
Grande. Future generations will appreciate fully the value of Dr.
Reed's services. His was the originating, directing, and control-
ling mind in this work, and the others were assistants only.”

Dr. William Welch, of Baltimore, Major Reed's teacher in bacteriology
and his intimate friend and confidant, said of him:

“Dr. Reed's researches in yellow fever are by far the most
important contributions to science which have ever come from
any Army surgeon. In my judgment they are the most valuable
contributions to medicine and public hygiene which have ever
been made in this country with the exception of the discovery
of anaesthesia. They have led and will lead to the saving of
thousands of lives. I am in a position to know that the credit
for the original ideas embodied in this work belongs wholly to
Maj. Reed.”

Dr. Howard Kelly, of Baltimore, accords Reed the following tribute of
of respect:

“******The inspiration of Reed's life lies to me in the fact
that, though a man of war, he ravaged no distant lands, he de-
stroyed no tens of thousands to make his reputation, but by
quiet methods, when there was no strife, he saved countless
lives and swept away a hideous plague, which from time immemorial
had periodically visited our shores, devastated our fair land,
and too often snatched from the years of peace and plenty all
their blessings.”

Major Reed died on November 23, 1902, of complications result-
ing from appendicitis. His remains were interred at Arlington, over-
looking the city of Washington, and the granite block over his grave
bears the strikingly appropriate inscription:
“He gave to man control over that dreadful scourge, Yellow Fever.”

In memory of the man and in commemoration of his great contribu-
tion to the world, the Army has named its most important general hospital--
“Walter Reed”.
